body:
> Mypy version used: 0.820+dev, 0.820

Can you provide the exact version `mypy -V` returns? It should look something like:
`mypy 0.820+dev.2ac722ac7d844f4c5ae2f3c36f3470543cf01b11`

> > Mypy version used: 0.820+dev, 0.820
> 
> Can you provide the exact version `mypy -V` returns? It should look something like:
> `mypy 0.820+dev.2ac722ac7d844f4c5ae2f3c36f3470543cf01b11`

I installed it with `pip3 install https://github.com/python/mypy/tarball/master`

```shell
$ mypy --version
mypy 0.820+dev
$ pip3 freeze | grep mypy
mypy @ https://github.com/python/mypy/tarball/master
```

Tried with the [instructions in the help](https://mypy.readthedocs.io/en/latest/common_issues.html#using-a-development-mypy-build). Gives same traceback but version

```shell
$ mypy --version
mypy 0.820+dev.bdcc5621d7a2f5124382662272d1be8476ec90fe
```
Thanks for the report, can repro with 0.812 and master. Possibly related to https://github.com/python/mypy/issues/9908
Yeah, so I think the issue is with member type aliases that don't alias to a concrete type. I have a dumb fix, let's see if it causes any regressions...

Fwiw, I think your code meant to do `CUSTOM_ATTRIBUTE: Optional[str]`

Here's a smaller repro:
```
from typing import Optional, Type


class ThreadedServer:
    def __init__(self, custom_server: Type["CustomServer"]) -> None:
        self.custom_server = custom_server
        self.custom_server.CUSTOM_ATTRIBUTE = "asdf"


class CustomServer:
    CUSTOM_ATTRIBUTE = Optional[str]
```

issue.title: INTERNAL ERROR when defining method argument type as class member in @runtime_checkable Protocol

labels.name: topic-type-alias
labels.description: TypeAlias and other type alias issues

issue.body:
Possibly related to: #9908, #10357, #10521, #10522.

**Crash Report**

```python
# $ cat mypy-bug.py
from typing import Protocol, Union
from typing_extensions import runtime_checkable
from operator import add as op_add

class Foo: pass

# FooAbleOperandT = Union[int, float, Foo, "FooAbleT"]  # <- this will work

@runtime_checkable
class FooAbleT(Protocol):
    FooAbleOperandT = Union[int, float, Foo, "FooAbleT"]  # <- this won't
    def __add__(self, other: FooAbleOperandT) -> Foo:
        return op_add(self.foo(), other)
    def __radd__(self, other: Union[int, float]) -> Foo:  # <- chokes here
        return op_add(other, self.foo())
    def foo(self) -> Foo: ...
```

**Traceback**

```sh
mypy-bug.py:14: error: INTERNAL ERROR -- Please try using mypy master on Github:
https://mypy.rtfd.io/en/latest/common_issues.html#using-a-development-mypy-build
Please report a bug at https://github.com/python/mypy/issues
version: 0.812
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "mypy/checker.py", line 401, in accept
  File "mypy/nodes.py", line 687, in accept
  File "mypy/checker.py", line 726, in visit_func_def
  File "mypy/checker.py", line 730, in _visit_func_def
  File "mypy/checker.py", line 792, in check_func_item
  File "mypy/checker.py", line 850, in check_func_def
  File "mypy/checker.py", line 1211, in check_reverse_op_method
  File "mypy/checker.py", line 1263, in check_overlapping_op_methods
  File "mypy/checker.py", line 1322, in is_unsafe_overlapping_op
  File "mypy/checker.py", line 5300, in is_unsafe_overlapping_overload_signatures
  File "mypy/subtypes.py", line 916, in is_callable_compatible
  File "mypy/subtypes.py", line 1040, in are_args_compatible
  File "mypy/subtypes.py", line 1045, in new_is_compat
  File "mypy/checker.py", line 5786, in is_overlapping_types_no_promote
  File "mypy/meet.py", line 184, in is_overlapping_types
  File "mypy/subtypes.py", line 1156, in is_proper_subtype
  File "mypy/subtypes.py", line 1177, in _is_proper_subtype
  File "mypy/types.py", line 833, in accept
  File "mypy/subtypes.py", line 1273, in visit_instance
  File "mypy/subtypes.py", line 539, in is_protocol_implementation
AssertionError:
mypy-bug.py:14: : note: use --pdb to drop into pdb
```

issue.title: Fix crash when using member type aliases in runtime contexts
issue.body:
This pull request:

- Fixes #10357
- Fixes #9908

Currently, checkmember.py attempts handling only type aliases with Instance targets and ignores type aliases with a special form target such as `Union[...]`, `Literal[...]`, or `Callable[...]`, causing either a crash or odd runtime behavior.

This diff replaces that logic (the `instance_alias_type` function) with the more general-purpose `alias_type_in_runtime_context` function found in checkexpr.py.

I'm not actually 100% sure if the latter is a perfect substitute for the former -- the two functions seem to handle Instance type aliases a little differently. But I think this is probably fine: the long-term benefits of consolidating mypy's logic is probably worth some short-term risk.

issue.title: Internal error: unresolved placeholder when using `--follow-imports=silent`
issue.body:
<!--
  Use this form only if mypy reports an "INTERNAL ERROR" and/or gives a traceback.
  Please include the traceback and all other messages below (use `mypy --show-traceback`).
-->

**Crash Report**

mypy had been crashing on my code for a long time now, because of an error in my code ([same reason as here](https://github.com/python/mypy/issues/10357#issuecomment-825224225)). I fixed that error, but it now crashes with the following traceback. 
Since it has been crashing for a long time, I did not manage to narrow it down to a specific part of my code, or write a minimal example, but I did find out that this crash only happens with the flag `--follow-imports=silent`. it does not crash with any other value for this flag


**Traceback**

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File ".venv/bin/mypy", line 8, in <module>
    sys.exit(console_entry())
             <function console_entry at 0x7ffad49cc430>
     <module 'sys' (built-in)>
  File ".venv/lib/python3.10/site-packages/mypy/__main__.py", line 12, in console_entry
    main(None, sys.stdout, sys.stderr)
                          <module 'sys' (built-in)>
               <module 'sys' (built-in)>
     <built-in function main>
  File "mypy/main.py", line 96, in main
    res, messages, blockers = run_build(sources, options, fscache, t0, stdout, stderr)
                               <built-in function run_build>
  File "mypy/main.py", line 173, in run_build
    res = build.build(sources, options, None, flush_errors, fscache, stdout, stderr)
           <module 'mypy.build' from '.venv/lib/python3.10/site-packages/mypy/build.cpython-31...
  File "mypy/build.py", line 154, in build
    result = _build(
  File "mypy/build.py", line 230, in _build
    graph = dispatch(sources, manager, stdout)
             <built-in function dispatch>
  File "mypy/build.py", line 2729, in dispatch
    process_graph(graph, manager)
     <built-in function process_graph>
  File "mypy/build.py", line 3087, in process_graph
    process_stale_scc(graph, scc, manager)
     <built-in function process_stale_scc>
  File "mypy/build.py", line 3205, in process_stale_scc
    graph[id].write_cache()
  File "mypy/build.py", line 2313, in write_cache
    new_interface_hash, self.meta = write_cache(
  File "mypy/build.py", line 1470, in write_cache
    data = tree.serialize()
  File "mypy/nodes.py", line 358, in serialize
    'names': self.names.serialize(self._fullname),
  File "mypy/nodes.py", line 3456, in serialize
    data[key] = value.serialize(fullname, key)
  File "mypy/nodes.py", line 3393, in serialize
    data['node'] = self.node.serialize()
  File "mypy/nodes.py", line 2915, in serialize
    'defn': self.defn.serialize(),
  File "mypy/nodes.py", line 1050, in serialize
    'type_vars': [v.serialize() for v in self.type_vars],
  File "mypy/types.py", line 535, in serialize
    'upper_bound': self.upper_bound.serialize(),
  File "mypy/types.py", line 2528, in serialize
    assert False, f"Internal error: unresolved placeholder type {self.fullname}"
AssertionError: Internal error: unresolved placeholder type None

```
When using the verbose mode, the last LOG line I get before the error is: 
`LOG:  Build finished in 8.065 seconds with 1177 modules, and 0 errors`

**To Reproduce**
I wasn't able to reproduce using a minimal example. I'd be happy to look for the root cause in my code if you have any insight on how to do that. The crash only happens with `--follow-imports=silent`

**Your Environment**

<!-- Include as many relevant details about the environment you experienced the bug in -->

- Mypy version used: 0.971
- Mypy command-line flags:  `--follow-imports=silent`
- Mypy configuration options from `mypy.ini` (and other config files): `python_version = "3.10"` 
- Python version used: 3.10.5
- Operating system and version: Ubuntu 20.04

<!--
You can freely edit this text, please remove all the lines
you believe are unnecessary.
-->
